channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: An XML representation of a search request

item.title: [AVRO-1789] Publish JS documentation
item.description: Matthieu Monsch wrote some great docs for the JS implementation in lang/js/docs. We should convert those to HTML and publish them as part of the website. All we need to do is to drop the HTML in build/avro-doc-<VERSION>/ during the build.sh dist target.

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [AVRO-1790] Publish avro-js to NPM
item.description: Looks like we haven't published the avro-js npm module yet. There's already an 'avro' module and I think the code is setup to produce avro-js. Matthieu Monsch, can you publish the 1.8.0 release artifact? You can find it here: http://ftp.wayne.edu/apache/avro/avro-1.8.0/js/

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Done! https://www.npmjs.com/package/avro-js
Can you add a note describing how to publish the module on the release page: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AVRO/How+To+Release. Thanks!
Tom White Sure, it doesn't look like I have edit rights though. (My username there is the same as here: `mtth`.)
Tom White, can you add me as well? I can't edit either.
I added you both so you should be able to edit the wiki now. Thanks!
Thanks Tom White! Just edited the page.

item.title: [AVRO-1791] Please delete old releases from mirroring system
item.description:
To reduce the load on the ASF mirrors, projects are required to delete old releases [1]

Please can you remove all non-current releases?
i.e. 1.7.7

Thanks!

[1] http://www.apache.org/dev/release.html#when-to-archive
item.summary: Please delete old releases from mirroring system

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment: -1 (non-binding) we need to keep 1.7.7 available as the latest release in the 1.7 line, since that line is not compatible with teh 1.8 line for several of the language-specific libraries.

Old releases are always available from the archive server:

http://archive.apache.org/dist/avro/

The ASF mirror servers are only for current releases, i.e. ones which are undergoing development.

As per [1] above
"When development ceases on a version branch, releases of that branch should be removed from /dist."

You can add a link to the archives server for older releases (but obviously the mirrors should be used for the current release(s))

Thanks for the policy link. I am aware of the ASF definition of current release lines. The 1.7 branch still exists in the Avro repo and jira shows that we have fixes that have landed and are waiting for the next 1.7.8 release. AFAICT, this counts as "undergoing development."

This really ought to be documented somewhere public.

The download page at present implies that 1.8.0 supersedes 1.7.7

If 1.7.7 is still needed for some users, this should really be made clear on the download page.

I agree with Sean, we still have a lot of people using the 1.7.x line and may certainly have another compatible release.

Sebb, what would you like to see in terms of documentation? The releases page just lists all of the releases and their dates. The downloads are organized as 1.7.7, 1.8.0, and stable (1.7.7). This is also consistent with our versioning, where bumping the minor version signals a breaking API change. I would normally expect a transition period as Sean is arguing for. Maybe we need to more clearly state what branches are active on the releases page? Clarify versioning there? Just let us know what would have made this more clear.

Although the download directory listing shows 3 folders, it's not particularly obvious which one to download.

You could add a README.html file with a bit more detail. This will show up at the bottom of the page.
Perhaps turn the existing README.txt into HTML?

However, it really would be better to provide more information on the download page.
At present that is quite difficult to read, and there is no information on how to verify the integrity of files [2]

The Accumulo download page [3] is very clear on what releases are active, and has a link to describe how to verify releases.
It uses links which directly download the archives, rather than requiring the user to navigate the download listing.
It would be better if it included individual hashes as done by Camel [4]

There are plenty of other examples.

[2] http://www.apache.org/dyn/closer.cgi#verify
[3] http://accumulo.apache.org/downloads/
[4] http://camel.apache.org/download.html
those sound like they'd be great improvements! Want to take a crack at making a draft change?

item.title: [AVRO-1792] Cannot specify a 'null' default value
item.description:
Using the new Schema.Field constructors added in 1.8.0, it is no longer possible to use the Java API to construct a schema field with a 'null' default value. That is, the following schema cannot be constructed without using the deprecated API:

{
	"type": "record",
	"name": "base",
	"fields": [{
		"name": "a",
		"type": ["null", "string"],
		"default": null
	}]
}

This is because passing a "null" value to the new API implies no default. Passing the "JsonProperties.NULL_VALUE" sentinel value doesn't work either, because when it is parsed by "JacksonUtils.toJsonNode", it turns into "null".

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Kevin J. Price, I thought that using JsonProperties.NULL_VALUE worked. Can you post a test case that demonstrates where this fails?
I'm glad it's working for you. Thanks for reporting bugs and also for following up on the resolution!

Whoops, put the resolution in the release note field. Moving to a fresh comment:

I was mistaken. I introduced a different bug when I made the change to using the 1.8 constructors. Whoops!

Using the NULL_VALUE constant does have the desired effect, still.

item.title: [AVRO-1793] Python2: Retain stack trace and original exception when failing to parse schema
item.description: Currently when a parse call fails the original exception is swallowed and replaced by a generic SchemaParseException. We should keep the original stack trace and include the actual exception message.
item.summary: Python2: Retain stack trace and original exception when failing to parse schema

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Patch with fix and unit test for same. Also removes relevant todo and fixes unrelated spelling error.

Hi Jakob Homan! Looks good to me, it's a shame that there's no better way of wrapping exceptions in python 2.

Maybe just two minor comments (not sure if this is the place for them):

+ I think the `str(e)` when you re-reraise is redundant since `%s` formatting will already do it.
+ Since you fixed the typo in the error message, could we lowercase the capital in "... requires All symbols ..." as well?
Hey Matthieu! Made the changes requested. Thanks for the review.
Thanks Jakob! Do you know if we should we wait for more reviews or commit this patch now? (I'm new here so not sure of the usual procedure.)

If you're comfortable with patch, you can go ahead and and +1 and commit. The python modules (both py2 and py3) seem to have been rather neglected over the years, which is something I hope to remedy soon. We're using this code a lot, so I expect to be putting up a bunch of patches to add.

Commit a50068f11e121bf87fa8bc24639af0fc62064633 in avro's branch refs/heads/master from Matthieu Monsch
[ https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=avro.git;h=a50068f ]

AVRO-1793. Python2: Retain original exception on schema parsing failure.

Contributed by Jakob Homan (jghoman).

Previously, when a parse call failed the original exception was
swallowed and replaced by a generic SchemaParseException. The original
stack trace is not retained along with the actual exception message.
Thanks Jakob Homan! Just committed the patch. Looking forward to more python improvements.

item.title: [AVRO-1794] Update docs after migration to git
item.description: The vote to move to git just passed. Once the INFRA ticket is completed, we will need to update docs.
item.summary: Update docs after migration to git

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: This one needs an update too https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AVRO/How+To+Contribute
Done. Thanks for pointing out the wiki page, Niels.

item.title: [AVRO-1795] Python2: Cannot parse nested schemas
item.description:
In the Java client, one can parse nested schemas by loading the nested schema before the nesting schema.

For example, a header can be defined in one file:

{ "namespace": "python.avro",
      "type": "record",
      "name": "header",
      "fields": [
         { "name": "header_field", "type": "string" }
       ]
    }

and then included in another schema:

{ "namespace": "python.avro",
      "type": "record",
      "name": "event",
      "fields": [
         {  "name": "header", "type": "python.avro.header" },
         {  "name": "event_field", "type": "string" }
      ]
    }

As long as one instantiates the Parser and loads the header first, the schemas will be reconciled and merged correctly.

However, the Python client does not support this. The parse method of the schema.py file always instantiates a new Names object to hold the schemas:

def parse(json_string):
  """Constructs the Schema from the JSON text."""
  # TODO(hammer): preserve stack trace from JSON parse
  # parse the JSON
  try:
    json_data = json.loads(json_string)
  except:
    raise SchemaParseException('Error parsing JSON: %s' % json_string)

  # Initialize the names object
  names = Names()

  # construct the Avro Schema object
  return make_avsc_object(json_data, names)

Some possible fixes for this are:
1) Create a separate Parser class to mimic the Schema.Parser Java approach, while deprecating the current parse method.
2) Include Names as a global variable to the parse method, allowing multiple parse calls to populate the same namespace. This breaks current behavior (and at least one unit test depends on it), so would be backwards compatible.
3) Create a new parse method that returns not only the schema, but also the Names instance and accepts that instance. This keeps the code nice and functional while exposing the Names class, which previously had been not particularly public.

I like the first approach.

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment: Found an example in http://gisgeek.blogspot.com/2012/12/using-apache-avro-with-python.html seems did what is required.

item.title: [AVRO-1796] Potential dead lock issue
item.description:
Usage of LogicalType in Schema can introduce a dead lock. It's due to the following change:

https://github.com/apache/avro/blame/master/lang/java/avro/src/main/java/org/apache/avro/Schema.java#L1326

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment: I gonna work a fix (basically, we should use the same lock in Schema and LogicalTypes result IMHO).

item.title: [AVRO-1797] Schema parser should not ignore null character in default value for bytes
item.description:
In https://avro.apache.org/docs/1.7.7/spec.html#schema_complex, "Default values for bytes and fixed fields are JSON strings, where Unicode code points 0-255 are mapped to unsigned 8-bit byte values 0-255.". The example provided is: bytes || string || "\u00FF".

However, if I try to create a table schema with default bytes value for a decimal field to be i.e. "\u0031", I will have "Illegal unquoted character ((CTRL-CHAR, code 31)): has to be escaped using backslash to be included in string value.". Anything less than 32 fails.
item.summary: Schema parser should not ignore null character in default value for bytes

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment: At least the C version of AVRO library is broken in bytes manipulation as well. JSON string cannot have any control character. Default value for all bytes backed type fails.

I should double escape \.. But '
u0000' is still a problem. For integer 786671, bytes code is \u000c\u0000\u00ef, and the middle \u0000 is ignored by the json parser.
The problem is that json string maps to C char array, but null is legal in bytes array but is string terminator in C string. Without string length info it is impossible to decode this default value.

On the C side we don't support default values at all yet; AVRO-1270 is the tracking bug for adding support for that.

Your point is still valid for rendering Avro values using the JSON encoding, though; for that, any bytes value will be truncated at the first NUL byte. The JSON library that we're using lets you pass in an explicit length for any strings, though (using the json_string_nocheck function), so it should be pretty easy to update src/value-json.c to call it and fix this. It's a pretty good starter bug if you want to take a stab at it; if not, I can probably look at this sometime this week or next.
Whoops! json_stringn_nocheck, that is — that extra n is important!

Thank you so much for this information!!.. I just realized avro started using systems Jansson library.. but I am working with a legacy version(1.7.x)... and does not have this function. I will see if I can cherry pick Jansson's \u0000 support and this one.

I could take this, but I am not sure which apis the latest code use are affected... since I came from a much smaller scope..
I will take another look later.

item.title: [AVRO-1798] WriteFixed throws an exception for a null Fixed value instance.
item.description:
Code generated with:
{"name": "MyShort", "type": ["null",

{"type": "fixed", "name": "short", "size": 2}

]},

When writing a record that has a null value for MyShort it throws the exception: "Fixed object is not derived from SpecificFixed"

At:
Avro.Specific.SpecificDatumWriter.WriteFixed()

when it tries to interpret the "value as SpecificFixed"

protected override void WriteFixed(FixedSchema schema, object value, Encoder encoder)

{ var fixedrec = value as SpecificFixed; if (fixedrec == null) throw new AvroTypeException("Fixed object is not derived from SpecificFixed"); encoder.WriteFixed(fixedrec.Value); }
item.summary: WriteFixed throws an exception for a null Fixed value instance.

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
